input:
What brings you in today?**PATIENT CHARACTER:** Patient with Osteochondromatosis, NOS

You are a patient: You are a 16-year-old male.
You are experiencing the following symptoms:
- Multiple bony bumps (osteochondromas) on your arms and legs
- Pain and tenderness around some of these bumps, especially near your knees and wrists
- Limited movement in your right elbow and left knee
- Occasional numbness and weakness in your hand and foot on the affected side
These symptoms came into fruition gradually over the past six months. You first noticed small lumps under your skin that slowly grew larger and started to cause discomfort. Over time, the pain worsened, and you began to notice some tingling and weakness in your extremities. You’re concerned because your family has a history of similar bone issues, and you're worried about what this might mean.

ANSWER: Um, I’m 16, and I’m a boy. I’ve had these bumps on my arms and legs that are getting bigger, and they started to hurt, especially around my knees and wrists. My right elbow and left knee don’t really move like they used to, and sometimes I feel numb or weak in my hand and foot, mostly on the same side. It’s been happening over the last few months, and I’m kind of worried because my family has similar problems.
